content:
Richard drives the Nissan
350Z convertible in Iceland!

And James drives the
Chrysler Crossfire convertible.
Guess where.

Hello, and welcome
to Top Gear.

Now, we get quite a few complaints
that we don't feature enough
affordable cars on the show.

So we're kicking off tonight with
the cheapest Ferrari of them all.

This is it.
The new Ferrari F430.

And I'm not going to
mess about. It's epic.

I've been driving around in it
now for a couple of days
and unlike any other supercar,

I haven't found
a single environment

where it's anything less
than spectacular.

On the motorway, coming down
here this morning, it was brilliant.

On country lanes,
it's brilliant.

In traffic, it's brilliant.
And here...
Oh, my God!

Ferrari are now on just
an all-new level.

They're way, way
beyond anyone else.

This things makes even
an Aston Martin DB9

or a Porsche Turbo
feel like a canal boat.
This car is just staggering.

I mean,
listen to this noise.

Those exhausts are only
waste disposal units,

but I've heard less tuneful
symphony orchestras.

So, let's have a look at what
makes this car so unbelievable.
Starting with the engine.

It's a brand new,
4.3 litre V8,

which develops
490 brake horsepower.

That means you can go
from 0-60 in four seconds

and on to a top speed of...
Well, let's find out.

Coming up now to
8,500 rpm from a V8.

My ears are starting
to bleed now.
Running out of runway.

Flat out with just
a hint of a tail wind,

it'll be nudging
200 miles an hour.
So, what about the handling?

The old Ferrari 360 was
a tricky little so and so.

So, is life any easier
in this?

Well, that rather depends on
where you have this little button here.

You see, you've got five
settings. Snow And Ice.

Not really relevant.
Normal Road use. Sport.

That makes the gearbox
more ferocious,

firms up the suspension,
increases the exhaust noise

and backs off the
traction control.

Race,
kind of more and harder.

And then CST, which turns
all the driver aids off.

Wonder what CST
stands for.
"Commit Suicide,
"Training."

Anyway it doesn't matter
we're on the track,
so let's put it in "Race".

We have ignition.
Launch control.

Yes, and it will
have some of that.
And, um...
We have lift off!
Oh, yes!

I can actually feel
the traction control now.

Letting me have a little bit
of a slide there in Race mode,
but not too much.

Making me look heroic,
but not letting me crash.

See that big slide there?
That was me doing that.

Nothing to do with this car's
brand new E differential.

The same diff they put in Michael
Schumacher's Formula One car.

They say that even the fattest,
most butterfingered driver

can get a 430 round the
Ferrari test track

only a second slower than
the best of the test drivers.

So the handling is like
the engine, brilliant.

And so are the brakes.
And so is the steering.
And so is the comfort.
And so is the quality.

Even the driving position
is perfect.

In fact, I'm struggling to think
of anything wrong with this thing.

I suppose it's not the
prettiest Ferrari ever made.

And the nose
is quite low.

You'd catch it
on speed humps.
And, um...

Oh, the electric
window switch.
It's a bit of a stretch.

That aside, this car sits in the
marketplace like a Harrier jump jet
at the Battle of Agincourt.
So, obviously, you want one.

But there are going to be
a few problems with that.

You see, the basic price
is £118,000.

And that's
not really so bad.

I mean, sell the house, sell the
children for medical experiments,

rob a bank,
you'll soon get that money.

But then you'll end
up in the showroom

where you'll be presented
with the options list.

And this is where
things get quite scary.

I mean, the stitching,
for example,

on the door here
and on the seats.

If you want that in a
different colour to the leather,

that's gonna
cost you £235.

Which seems like quite
a lot for what's basically
a few feet of cotton.

Then there's the leather
which you can have here

behind the seats
where you can't see it.

And if you want your
brake calipers red, 500 quid.
If you want them yellow, £560.

Sports seats which are
exactly the same as these seats

but less comfortable,
they are £3,175.

Flappy panel gearbox, really
pricey, I'm afraid. 6,000 quid.

Although, because you
don't need a clutch pedal,

you could raise that money
by selling one of your legs.

And then there's the
carbon ceramic brakes.

To be brutally honest, you don't
really need any of this garnish.

But there is one option that
you might be interested in.
For an extra £8,000,

you can have this car with a
roof that in just 20 seconds can be

folded into a cubby hole
behind the seats.
Sounds great.
But don't be too hasty.
You see, in a normal car

the front end and the back end are
joined together by the floor and the roof.

If you remove the roof, you end
up with something all kind of...

Flobbery. Anyone who drove
an early Saab convertible

will know what
I am on about.

So to compensate, engineers
have to fit lots of strengthening beams
which add weight.

And weight spoils the
performance, it spoils the handling,

it spoils the economy,
it spoils everything.

Ferrari admit that this car is
not quite so brilliant as the coupe.

But they're adamant that
the shortfalls are so minute,
you can't really spot them.

To find out, we've put a
Ferrari test driver in the coupe

and now we're going to see
if he can pull away from me
in this.
Here we go!
He's very good, this bloke.

Getting away from me a bit
here, but I'm pulling him back.

I can't tell you
how good this feels!

Madman!
Mad Italian man!

So the convertible really is
as fast as the coupe.

It's even more striking,
you get the wind in your hair,

and you can hear that amazing
soundtrack even more clearly.

Plainly, then, you're going
to say to the salesman, "Yes.
"I'll have the convertible."

Nice idea, but it could very well be
the biggest mistake of your entire life.
And here's why.

With the roof down, people
can see your bald patch.
They can see your stomach.

And they can hear the CD
that you're playing.

So you'll end up
with what is very possibly

the greatest driving
machine ever made.

And it'll make you look
like a complete dork.

I have to say, I'm not the world's
sportiest driver, as you know,
but I have driven these two,

and they are chuffing
magic, absolutely.

When I was driving this in Italy, a
man had to get me out with a stick.

No, they are, honestly.
When you get in a Ferrari now,

this is absolutely true,
it's like no other car.

They are just
completely different.

Yeah, I know. When you get out
of an Aston Martin into a Ferrari,

you sort of feel like you've
gone forward another 200 years.

Yeah, absolutely, but we've still
got this convertible conundrum.

Who here, of the two,
would choose the soft top?
Hands up.

Let's have a look.
Who'd choose it?
You'd choose the soft top?
You'd... Yes?

- Yeah, I would, Jeremy.
- Why?
It's nice.

Yeah, but do you think that
we want to look at your face
behind the wheel of that?

- Yeah, why not?
- Because it's horrid.

Keep your hands up,
let's have a look around.

Who else would go
for the convertible?

There were more hands
than that a minute ago!

Now you've all suddenly
gone all timid.

The thing you've got to
remember is this,

if when you look in the mirror,
you look like Jose Mourinho,

then you can have
the soft top.

If when you look in the mirror
you look like Jose Pasquale...
Then you can't.
I mean, let me demonstrate...

Which one would
you rather have?
The hard top, fine, okay.

- Now look at this. Would you like to step inside?
- Mmm-hmm.
You step inside there.

And I'll just show
something to you, okay?

- Easier said than done.
- There we are. You're in.

Now this is perfect because
he's having the time of his life

and we don't have to
look at him.
Anyway, we must now find out

how fast this goes
round our track.

Which means of course we must
hand it over to our tame racing driver.

Some say that his heart
ticks like a watch.

And that he's
confused by stares.

All we know is
he's called The Stig.

Oh, away he goes. Masses
of wheel spin off the line.

And of course, Stig has
all the electronics off

'cause he has the talent
to handle the power.

That and the fact he fears
neither pain nor death, of course.

First corner looking smooth.
That is very flat, very neat.
Textbook stuff.

Stig enjoying the sounds
of Greenslade there.

Bedside manners are extra.
Chicago.
Oh, now, look at that.

The car flat and in the hands
of an expert, it is unstoppable.

Look at him through
the Hammerhead.

Easing on the power.
Clever diff working its magic.

Actually that's quite a
poor song, to be honest.

Now, here he comes
into the follow-through.

Changes up a bit,
but he hasn't lifted.
The tyres...

We've had Aston Martin Le Mans
racer and an F1 car through there.

Nothing has hit the tyre wall
with that much violence.

He's only got Gambon to go. This is
gonna be quick if he can keep it together.
And across the line.
No! No, pipe down!
We analysed that footage.

The Stig actually
hit the tyres.

He was cutting it so fine
there was a line of rubber

all down the side of the
Ferrari when he finished.

Even so, do you want
to know what time he did?
Yes.
122.9, which is there.

The really amazing thing
though is that we also sent

the Spider around,
the convertible.

Only .3 of a second slower,
which is just absolutely remarkable.

It is incredible, but shall I show
you something really incredible?

Look at this, 122.9.
The old Ferrari 360, 122.3.
0.6 of a second faster.

Now there is
a reason for that.

Quite apart from the fact this
was the Challenge Stradale,

The Stig and the
Ferrari test driver say

that the 430 is slower
'cause it runs on Bridgestones,

and the old 360
was on Pirellis.

So, if you're in the Ferrari
showroom specing your car up,

forget the flappy paddle
carbon ceramic stitching, okay?

Just say to them, "Get
those Bridgestones off it."

- Okay.
- That's quite boring, actually.

It's very difficult to make tyres
interesting. I apologise for that.

But anyway, let's move on
and do the news.
Yes, and Nismo.

Now, they are to Nissan
what AMG are to Mercedes.

They're a tuning house that
work on their cars for them.
They did, they did that...

They did the Skylines,
didn't they, in the olden days?

They did, sort of 800
brake horsepower jobs.

Well, they've now done
a 350Z. Here it is.

It's got 295 brake horsepower,
which is a bit more.

It's lighter than usual. Naught
to 60 in five and a half seconds,
costs you about £33,000.

You know what the
best thing about this is?

It's got something
called G-Attack Suspension!

- Yes, it has!
- I've no idea what that is, but I want that!

'Cause I have the mental
age of a six-year-old.

I'm there, and I'd appreciate

Gotta say, though, why are
Nismo messing around doing this,

when what they should be doing
is bringing us a new Skyline?

Remember the old one?
We've got a picture of it here.
There's the old one, okay?

Now, that was about
as good as cars got. Okay?

And that's what I want,
is a new one of those.

- It was fabulous.
- That's an awful car.

That's an awful car. The
thing about these cars is...

They're, well, look... They're
lumpy, bumpy, they've got spoilers,

they usually have stupid wheels,
they've got bulges on the bonnet,

they've got a shiny interior,
they're driven by

idiots in baseball caps on
the wrong way around.

- Has anybody here got a gun?
- Yeah!

That is a dreadful car, it's
got pop-up screens and things.
You know what I'd like?

I'd like that new version
of the Rolls Royce,

'cause it comes with some pens
in the glove box. Have a look.
That's what you want.

Like I said, "Has anyone
got a gun?" A knife?

Anything that
we could kill him with.
Maybe a G-Attack Suspension!

Yes, I want to hit you over

Now, last year we drove pretty
well all the cars from the Pacific Rim,

and I decided
that the worst of the lot,

and there were
some pretty bad ones,
uh, was the Kia Rio.
No, no, it wasn't.

It was that Hyundai

Oh, you're right,
you're right.

The second worst car,

Well, they've brought out

Now, Kia say that "It's

They say, "It's exciting and aimed at

- Really?
- You want to see it?
Yes.
Oh, yes.

You're a young person

- It's awful.
- It is awful, you couldn't...

I couldn't have

What it is, it's for people who

Old people go into the

That should be Kia's

"The Kia Rio,
it'll see you out, sir."
Yes, exactly.

Yes, anyway, have you seen

on the windscreens of
cars in showrooms?

They're like the ones you get

They're like the energy stickers, it

Look, that's the range of

for things like the
Toyota Prius,

and red, at the other end, is for,
sort of, Ferraris and supercars.

And the good thing is,
it's made it much quicker

going into a showroom,
and choosing a car.

Absolutely, you just go
for the red ones.

- Yes.
- Yeah.

Red ones will
all be interesting,

and the green ones
will all be just...

- Boring.
- Boring.

Yeah, exactly. And there's
another advantage as well,

actually to buying red cars,

that if we all drive real gas

the ice caps will melt,
the sea level will rise.

They produced a map to show

- Wales is cut off!
- Hey!
Look at that!

If you buy red... Oh, and I know

Look at it the other
way around.
England's cut off!

The map business

It's getting very

A few weeks ago, on the

This is a map

They say it's the perfect

Well, yes, it is,

One more piece of news.

Anyone seen Heatmagazine

- Okay.

They've done a...
They've done a list.

No, no.
They've done a list

What's it called?

"Weird people

- And they've got people like...

Oh, Boris Johnson

Really hideous people!
You know who's won it?
Richard Hammond.
Oh, yeah!
Thanks.

There are four people

Men fancy Hammond.

"He's a snappy dresser."

About dogs!
I don't have a clue about...

Well, he's obviously

He is more appealable than me

You can put him

He's not bad.

Yeah, now has anybody seen

Yes.

There is a 15,000 watt

15,000 watts is the sort of

playing the

So...

Good track.

But we're gonna kill

Thanks. See, sadly

Top Gear'spolicy when it

We don't go to the

That's why, in the past,

With this lot, though,

I absolutely love this place.

as old as that view.
The Audi TT.
It's been the daddy forever.

When I first drove a TT, must

I remember thinking
that its handling was rather
numb and inert.
But it turned out I was wrong.

The handling wasn't
numb and inert.
It was dangerous.

flick out just like that,

But guess what?

TT drivers, or titties,

and very well thought out.

the end.
